content.title: Cranial Nerve Preservation in CEA
content.definition: Surgical anatomy and techniques for preservation of cranial nerves at risk during carotid endarterectomy, including the vagus, hypoglossal, glossopharyngeal, and marginal mandibular nerves.

concepts.definition: Vagus nerve anatomy and injury consequences.

clinical_features.location: Posterior to carotid sheath, between ICA and IJV
clinical_features.branch: Superior laryngeal nerve - external branch may be injured

clinical_features.location: Crosses ICA from lateral to medial at level of bifurcation
clinical_features.consequence: Tongue deviation toward injured side, dysarthria, dysphagia
clinical_features.protection: Identify early, retract gently, avoid excessive traction

concepts.definition: Glossopharyngeal nerve during high carotid exposure.

clinical_features.location: Deep to styloid process, crosses ICA high
clinical_features.consequence: Difficulty swallowing, loss of gag reflex
clinical_features.risk: Higher with high bifurcation or redo surgery

clinical_features.location: Crosses mandible, may be injured with high exposure
clinical_features.consequence: Droop of corner of mouth, asymmetric smile
clinical_features.prevention: Incision below mandible angle, minimize retraction

clinical_features.most_common: Hypoglossal and marginal mandibular most frequently injured
clinical_features.recovery: Most injuries are temporary (neuropraxia), recover in weeks-months
